description.text: Lid extension for the Flashforge Dreamer

Printed at 0.2 layer height with 30% infill using PHA/PLA blend filament.
3mm plexi glass cut at 413mm X 140mm for the front and rear panels. 3mm X 264mm X 140mm for the side panels.

I wanted to still be able to remove the plexi glass panels, what I did was install all the components including the plexi glass and lid. I then ran a bead of gel super glue on each of the corner posts and left it to dry overnight (complete assembly plexi glass and lid, as this keeps everything square and you can place a few books on the lid to weight it down).
I am now able to side out any of the panels in order to print PLA or for easy access to the extruder's I can slide out just the front panel.

This does make the lid extension a permanent fixture, but I don't see myself wanting to remove it.

comments.text: Very nice addition, thanks.
comments.author: fox3

comments.text: This is great.  The one it came with was not suitable for printing.  I currently have to go with no lid.  Not to mention the fact that I don't even use the interior spool holders anymore because of their poor feeding design.
comments.author: BTK7

comments.text: Thanks, I often print with ABS and need to keep the build chamber closed but the standard lid would cause the filament to twist and deform sometimes causing breaks. The standard feed method for filament also causes it to wear the plastic on the top of the extruder, with the lid I was able to install the filament guide tube which works and looks better.

A mute for a cello designed based on measurements of my cello's bridge. Had to add a band of plastic on the bottom to prevent the parts from falling apart when printing. It fits perfectly, but seems that it doesn't seem to make the cello any quieter! :( My guess is the gap in the middle is too wide. I designed it on paper and then on google sketchup.
I printed it on a Prusa i3 from makerfarm.

comments.text: Could you make a universal mute
comments.author: kitepython

comments.text: Hi -  actual cello player here.   The mute appears to be placed wrong in that photo, or perhaps it's the perspective.  The mute should NOT touch the strings (perhaps unlike some violin mutes).  The five legs go outside all strings and in between the strings.  If the inner legs are touching the strings, you'll need to move them over a bit.  The mute works by deadening the vibrations in the bridge, not in the strings.
comments.author: cellocgw

comments.text: Would you consider dipping it in Plastidip or coating it with Sugru?
comments.author: abermanGSP

comments.text: Usually mutes are made of rubber and touch the strings to deaden them or are made of a dense material like metal and prevent the bridge from vibrating. Do you have a mute you are copying or are you trying to make one completely on your own?
comments.author: cyclone

comments.text: I am basing it on a violin mute I have but with a slightly different design to make it easier to create in 3d modelling.

Here are 4 pencil holders based on the Archimedean solids. They are constructed from just two elements, hypocycloids and spheres. Stl files are: truncated_cube.stl
truncated_octahedron.stl
rhombi_cuboctohedron.stl and
truncated_cuboctohedron.stl. OpenSCAD code is included.

All of the pencil holders can be constructed direcly on the build platform  
The smaller faces were omitted from the rhombi cuboctohedron and the truncated cuboctohedron by commenting out instructions in the openSCAD code.  It was felt that the open models were more attractive.  The omitted faces can be included by reversing the operation in the openSCAD programs.

This is a model which download from a japanese webside (http://www.weekend-makers-lab.com/make_data/1770).I found that the quality is bad if print in whole body and small in FDM printer. Therefore I try to separate it into different part for more easy to print.
I suggest to use Meshmixer to build support because it got little touch point and I suggest magnify to print because the small detail can be keep.

I print it in 0.1mm PLA and color it . It good looking ~~!! Special thank to jonahl of HKEPC

Our spa controller wasn't sealing properly and it turned out the sockets that accept the screws to hold the two halves together had snapped off on 3 of the 4 corners.

There was a bit left on each of them which I used as a guide to locate a new printed socket to replace the broken ones. Trying to describe this is pretty tricky so I've included quite a few photos.

I doubt the STL will be useful to anyone (unless you've got a Hurlcon Pool / Spa Controller) but I hadn't come across the idea before and thought I'd share it.

Flow rate and feed rate are no longer difficult to calibrate, thanks to stepper extruders.  However, to really get your print quality to the next level, you will need to calibrate temperature and reversal settings for a given material. (and/or travel feed rate, depending on your machine) This is a fully parametric calibration test for both bridging and gap distances within the same part.
Bridging is a great test for temperature.  If the bridge is too saggy, the temperature is too high.  There are also some advantages to higher temperatures though, one of which is it makes the thermoplastic less viscous, creating less work for the motor.  If your preference is printing really hot, a fan concentrating cool air on the extrudate can also be used to calibrate bridging.
Traversing large gaps is obviously a great test for reversal/travel speed settings.  Set extra shells to 0 to avoid hiding any ooze behind inner perimeters.  Make the infill very low to save printing time since you only care about spanning gaps for this test.  Use a camera for feedback if you are extra picky about strings.  
Good Luck.

To customize your test, open the script with OpenSCAD, and edit the variables labeled at the top. Once you are finished, select "Compile and Render" or press F6. //PRIMARY INPUTS
minimum reversal gap distance (mm)
maximum reversal gap distance (mm)
minimum bridging distance (mm)
maximum bridging distance (mm)
number of steps
total height of object (mm) //SECONDARY INPUTS
width of vertical tower (mm)
width of border on base plane (mm)
thickness of border on base plane (mm)
thickness of bridges (mm)

comments.text: Interesting, the perimeters of the bridges go flawlessly, but the infill in between, the printer just 'buzzes' or 'pulsates' and the line falls in between the perimeter lines of the bridge.
comments.author: Ohmarinus

comments.text: Don't worry about this issue too much, it is dependent of how intelligent the slicing software is.  Whenever extruded filament attaches infill to a perimeter, the software is telling it to move just enough to contact the perimeter, and if that perimeter is dangling in the air, it doesn't have a very good chance of succeeding flawlessly.  If the imperfections still bother you, you can adjust the infill angle to start at 180degrees and rotate 180degrees every layer.  This will force the software to have bridging infill in the same direction as the bridge on all layers, and your problem will go away
comments.author: Ohmarinus

comments.author: Starno

comments.text: It's advantageous to rotate the angle of infill for most objects but not on the first few layers of bridges.  Only change it if you want to verify that is your problem, but I wouldn't suggest using those settings all the time.

title: Geeetech Delta Rostock Kossel Mini G2/G2S Carriage (Modified)

description.text: If you own a Geeetech Delta Rostock Kossel Mini G2/G2S kit, this part may be of interest to you. I found the the printed carriage parts had tolerances that were entirely too tight to fit the rubber toothed belt into the belt drive slots. I have also designed a snap on cover for the carriage that covers the belt drive. Once I finalize that piece, I will add it to this thing.

I modified this part at www.tinkercad.com. I added hole objects to the existing unmodified object from Geeetech to increase the gap between the teeth and the retaining wall of the belt drive end connections.

title: Reversible Elastic Band PCB vice vise

description.text:
This elastic band powered PCB vice is ideal for holding your parts.

An optional cable clamp can be used to hold wires and cables in place while you solder.

The print is 180mm x 100mm x 14mm and is printed as a single item.

Update. Smaller 150mm x 80mm version added for those with a smaller build platform.

An optional cable clamp can be used to retain wires etc. while you solder. I haven't actually built and tested the clamp yet. If you do then please let me know in the comments.

You will require 2 (3 if using the cable clamp) light duty elastic bands.

I currently need to borrow a friends printer to make these things. I am saving to buy my own 3D printer so any donations, tips and comments would be most welcome.

Also please contact me if you would like to use this design for commercial purposes.

I designed this for my Mamba3D 3d-printer and it's done in OpenSCAD with all parameter defined up front, so you probably can modify this easily to something else. I wrote a blogpost on how i got this to work on my 3dprinter:
http://www.oiepoie.nl/2015/09/19/auto-tramming-or-leveling-for-a-mamba3d-3dprinter/

The OpenSCAD program is a little messy, but i will put it up for download so anyone can adopt it to it's own needs.

The design is driven by the goeal to make it a rigid product, so it doesn't vibrate much when the extruder moves to the measurement point for auto-tramming.
I printed it with 30% honycomb infill.

On the bottom there is a nice hex indent for the 12mm hex nut to fit into.
http://www.oiepoie.nl/2015/09/19/auto-tramming-or-leveling-for-a-mamba3d-3dprinter/

Mount for Xiaomi Yi onto a ZMR 250 quadcopter.

Updated to version 2, this mount sits at a 20 degree angle, and has an even wider hole through the bottom to be able use a battery strap / velcro to hold it down.

Based on feedback version 2 also reduces the back support so that it is at 90 degrees and can enable you to have a battery pack right up against it. This will help you achieve a better balanced quad.

For best result, print with supports enabled. Depending on your printer you may need to enlarge the screw holes a tiny bit for mounting.

Edit: Added a 30 degree version (V1, V2 is still in the making) at request of Zackc19....

Have fun and let me know if you built one!
Nothing much to say here... use supports and print in your favourite material - I have printed succesfully with ABS.

description.text:
A nice carry case to transport your SpaceNavigator 3D Mouse. Comes with interlocking lid. The heavy SpaceNavigator fits snuggly inside and does not move.

Printed in PLA at 0.3mm height with no supports. Tolerances are fairly close so make sure your printer is properly calibrated.

The lid should snap into place without having to force it.

Print in PLA or plastic of your choice. I made mine (and all the prototypes) in PLA with 0.3mm height and 15% infill. I probably wouldnt bother going over 0.2mm height or 20% infill.

Should be nice and easy to print. No supports needed.

But the lid is a fairly close fit, with only 0.4mm of play. So if you are overextruding or your printer is screwed, you may find the lid wont fit.

The Dead End protects your Ethernet (RJ45) cables.

Two things about LAN cables:

  1. We all know that Ethernet cables are social beings. Put them nicely in a bag and you can be sure that they are tangled together when you pull them out again.
  2. Those darn plastic things on the connectors WILL break when you try to untangle the mess.

The Dead End cable protector is to your rescue!
Simply clip the Dead End cap over the connector and you will never break that plastic thing again!

Dead End can also be used in data centers etc. to indicate a free cable or a missing connection.

The print is quite simple and optimized to use as little time and filament as possible.

I designed this motor mount to mount a 12 V DC motor to a piece of plywood. The motor can be found cheaply on ebay here

http://www.ebay.com.au/itm/161777108766?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AI

The dimensions of the motor are as follows

Shaft diameter: 4mm
Product dimensions: 25mm

I made the hole in the middle 5.5mm to suit the fixed spacer on the
front of the motor and it fits snuggly and would hold in place without screws for light applications.

I printed it face down in pla with 10% infill with supports to support
the base lugs with a raft and it took 39 minutes.

title: Modified Gantries for Ultimaker 2 Aluminum Extrusion 3D printer

description.text:
In order for my flange-bearings to fit into the Gantries for the awesome build over at: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:811271 I had to modifiy the size of hole/s for the bearings and rods.

See the image for dimensional details. It is the same changes done to all pieces.

I have added 1 (for now) "extended" version of one of the gantries. It is clearly named. A Photo is also added.
Gantry-X-axis-back-left-modified-extended
Extended the Gantry in both ends to allow for mount/dismount of the Gantry after assembly.
Can remove it without first removing endstop.
Space for the use of washers.

I'll recommend printing these with proper infill. Like 100% to make them to last.

You do not need to scale these as my work on them did that.

comments.text:

Now I can get back to it.

This kit updates your Switchblade 250 Tricopter to a Trident 250. The Trident uses the same hardware as the Switchblade but replaces the front folding carbon tube arms with fixed printed arms. This reduces the overall parts count and cost of the design. To build this tricopter you will need to also download parts and follow the instructions found in the Switchblade 250 "thing" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:755420

This kit includes a left and right arm, and printable bushings which replace the ball bearings in the Switchblade frame. Four (4) additional M3 self tapping screws will be needed, but you can use the same length ones used to secure the tail boom in the Switchblade.

Keep an eye out for a full Trident 250 Tricopter "thing" which will include all files needed to built a Trident 250 Tricopter along with simplified arm mounting and reduced printed part count.

Please see Switchblade 250 page for instructions and parts list.

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:755420/#instructions

I'd be happy to mail you the file in case anybody else experiences the missing posts.  I use Makerbot Desktop to print on a FlashForge Creator Pro.  On the antenna arm, the holes for the servo horn screw and for the ball bearing ring were slightly non-concentric, so I moved the ball bearing ring hole 0.132mm in X and 0.122mm in Y.  Probably not that critical, but I love having everything align.  I can mail you that file also if you want it. Thanks again for posting this design and great instructional video,

title: CR-7: 40mm fan duct to nozzle (ring type)

description.text:
Printer CR-7 has no nozzle fan. I design this fan duct for setup the second fan to cold down target quicker.

Advantages:
1.Design for CR-7, only use one screw hole.
2.No need other screw to install fan.
3.Won't be fused by hot head.
4.Nozzle fan makes effective benefits on bridge test.

Disadvantage:
1.Cover the path. If you want to use foldback clip to fasten the flat, you have to clip it in the right side.
2.You have to put this duct in the "good" position exactly, or it may touch the hot head.
3.Fast cold down may make some adverse effects for stick layer together.

description.text: Just and aggressive feline design with an automatic jaw. It is a work in progress design but this first version is amazing!

For printing feline I have used RepetierHost with a 0.2 layer, 40% of filling and generating supports. After printing simply remove the supports, put a little or strong spring if you like and you're done.

I have made three Bird Feeder things - the latest being version 4: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:359618 - but filling them when attached to the window is always a bit messy.
I have tried using a standard funnel and also a newspaper rolled up into a funnel shape and although this is a little bit more flexible I always end up spilling bird seed onto the floor.

This thing is nothing more than a funnel with an angled spout but it makes the job so much easier.

EDIT: Although it didn't need it as I printed and used the first version of the funnel which is shown in the photographs without any problems, I had another play with my CAD application and reworked the design to have thicker walls (1.6mm rather than 1.2mm on the first version) and a smoother "bend". The STL for the second version is FUNNEL2.STL. Just to stress - the first version works perfectly well, I just wanted to make it more elegant perhaps :-)

Printed on my Mendel90 which enables a print height in the order of 200mm. The funnel goes to within 5mm of this maximum height so you may wish to scale it should your printer require something smaller.

Infill is somewhat irrelevant as the walls are relatively thin so I kept a standard (for me) 25%.

(And if you are interested .... sliced using Skeinforge)

These handles work well around my printer. They hold a 2 mm & 2.5 mm wrench.

The handle below the hex portion is hollow. I used a # 44 drill bit for the 2 mm wrench and a #36 drill bit for the 2.5 mm. Just drill the undersized hole to fit the wrench you want to use.

I drilled the handle in a lathe for a nice hole on axis.

The short leg of the wrench was hit with a grinder, broken off in a machinist vice and flattened on the end.

Press fit.

Scaling is another option for different sizes.
z axis and y axis to fasten one.

description.text: I lost this item, so I made a new one. It is needed, to keep the BOSCH MUM5 Citrus attachement turning smooth and centered.

A simple, blinky, 3D printed necklace you can wear to spark interesting conversations! The 3D printed chassis fits a LoL Shield & Diavolino inside. A battery pack can be attached to the back to keep the blinkiness powered. The faceplate was designed to be only 4 layers thick (2 layers for the lightning bolt area), so the light can shine through. With the white LEDs, it's visible in daylight. Here is the blog post where we discuss more about the necklace. In the .zip file, you will find the .stl and raw Inventor files (except we removed the lightning bolt, feel free to come up with your own design!)

A custom skirt for the SWH170 fpv miniquad.
The following changes are made from the original:

  • Holes for "googly eyes" (18mm in diameter)
  • Integrated tail lights, fits 10mm pcb addressable RGB LEDs
  • Hole for an integrated XT60 connector
  • Bigger hole for FPV camera
  • Hole for Naze USB connector made smaller (Naze mounted upside down)
  • Smaller cutouts for wires

Now there's also a version without holes for googly eyes
The skirt can be printed without support. There are some support already in the stl under the tail lights, just break them off after printing.

This is a multi-part revolver from guild wars 2. The files are a bit polygonal, but i made this a while ago and i think ti turned out well for what i was capable of at the time. The Revolver Cylinder spins in place.

There really isn't a good way to print most of the parts without having overhangs so you will have to be careful using supports and rafts. I would use many shell layers so that the smaller flanges and vines wont be so easily broken. Also, the gun is put together with glue, this is from before i was comfortable creating snap fits.

description.text: Simple bracelet design.
Cleaned up the SketchUp source to the point where the STL can be cleaned in netfabb and come out the other end as one shell.

• Download the sketchup source.

  • Export as .dae

  • Open .dae model in MeshLab and Save As STL.

  • Add STL to a netfabb project and run a default mesh repair on it.

  • Export the resulting fixed mesh as STL.

  • Import the STL into RepG and scale+center as required to slice.

description.text:
I'd been finding it a little too easy to snap off the aerial tubes on impact (especially with shop bought prints).

Greg @ ZAxis3D has made a key modification to korylprince's work that provides greater strength and doubles as a print support for the protruding aerial tubes.

I'm using these modified versions on both a Vortex and an Emax Nighthawk. The combination of both 36mm mounting holes and zip tie slots make it a very versatile item to fit.

UPDATE:
This should also fit the X4R and X4R-SB as the dimensions are the same.

comments.text: Cool! I'm glad someone is making use of it. I'm preparing a new design to deal with a few of the problems I have with the original: The arms interfering with the back mounting holes and the arm angle not clearing the top plate of the ZMR 250 when mounted on top of the naze32.
comments.author: korylprince

comments.text: On the Vortex, don't you have the problem of one or both back arms folding up during a crash, and the props colliding with the bottom of the V antenna arms? On a similar design, had this occur this morning! Broke the props and one of the arms... looking for a different design. There is a remix that points the V aft, instead of up.
comments.author: mepster

comments.text: I've not had that issue on my Vortex and my props spin about a cm above the top of the V of the mount (thus they'd hit the plastic tubes which are pretty flexible and replaceable). I have aft pointing antenna's on my Thug and it's proved frustrating in terms of catching them on things when transporting the quad.
comments.author: mepster

comments.text: The STL I am downloading is all sorts of messed up. My slicer mutilates it. Import it into Tinkercad and it is really weird....
comments.author: Cheezwiz

comments.text: Indeed, the geometry is very screwed up. It has both non-manifold edges and self intersecting surfaces. Netfabb can't even fix it completely. Un-sliceable with Simplify 3D. This is what often happens when people try to hack someone else's STL file. The original design by korylprince had solid manifold geometry and sliced just fine. I sometimes wish people would get a good CAD program and create a new design from scratch if they thought they could improve something.
comments.author: Cheezwiz

title: Rubber band powered coconut flinging Monkey!

description.text:
This monkey will fling things over it's head and into a target (if you're any good). Print a couple and use them as a fun game for kids. The ammo can be anything you like, coconuts, bananas, or even monkey dung!

https://youtu.be/FEBva_tFHS8

Can be printed without support.

Inspired by the game 'Coconuts', I wanted to see if I could make my own monkey from scratch. Created solely in Sketch-Up.

==UPDATE==
It seems that too many rubber bands or excessive use can lead to his head falling off! To eliminate this I am redesigning the join so it is more robust. I have also improved the throwing angle to be more vertical, and made the hands more cupped to hold the projectile's better. The fixed models are suffixed with v2.

Note, due to printer issues I have been unable to test v2, so let me know if there are any issues.

Print out the 3x parts. Clean up the axle and slot so it pivots smoothly. Insert 1-2 rubber bands through the holes in the bottom, fish them out with a small screwdriver or hook and clip them over the hook on the arms. Slot the head on (I had to clean up the top surface to ensure the head slots on properly). Print out some ammunition and some target cups (or find something suitable), and FLING! Rules for Coconuts game can be found online, or make up your own variations.

FEET TO GO OVER ALUM. POST HELD ON WITH SCREW AND HOT GLUE 4 NEEDED MADE FOR EMAX 250 NIGHTHAWK PRO CARBON FIBER FRAME THESE ALSO HAVE HOLLOWED OUT CENTERS SO DON'T FREAK WHEN AN H SHAPE STARTS TO APPEAR

This is my car from the game Rocket League. I modeled it myself and have tried to make it as printable as possible, though the chassis proved very difficult to do that with. I hate using supports but I had to acquiesce this time.

These parts will need supports

  • Chassis
  • Back Wheel Bumper
  • Front Wheel Bumper
  • Frame

The rest should be printable without supports.

I have two versions of the chassis. One has the bumpers built in. This makes them somewhat easier to print and they look better when done, but the support material can be a bit difficult to take off without breaking the bumper/armor pieces off. So you can use the other Chassis + the invidual bumper pieces if you prefer.

You will need
1 Chassis (+ 1 FrontWheelBumer and 2 BackWheel Bumper if not printing the chassis_noWheelBumpers)
2 Spikes
2 Air Brakes
2 Front Axle Washers
2 Back Axle Washers
2 Back Wheels
2 Front Wheels
1 Front Axle (recommended: substitute a piece of coat hanger)
1 Back Axle (recommended: substitute a piece of coat hanger)
1 Engine

The washers are to stop the axle from sliding around as the wheels roll. If you don't care about the wheels rolling, you can omit these and just glue the axle in place.

I went ahead and printed the axles, but I cut a length of coat hanger as it is far more durable for the moving part.

The bumpers/armor pieces are a bit of a pain. I tried printing them seperately and as part of the car. If you are doing it as part of the car, be very careful removing the supports.

Block_Width = 2

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/akXWAlTkfCe

Within the first five minutes of reading the paper on the Hyper Loop I thought, what about safety? My first design is a "just in case" it would be highly unlikely for the tube to come in contact with the pod. However, if it did at those high speeds what would happen? My mind went to a wheel and that was quickly turned from since land speed records show that rubber must be replaced with metal at some point. Another reason to reject a wheel design is the amount of daily maintenance and system checks. The complexity of the design is just too large. Bearings, struts, bolts, and so on. Within just a few more minutes I came up with a Teflon sponge idea in which a lubricant in the form of a gel at normal temperatures could be suspended. An instructor (nameless until wishing to be named) quickly tossed an idea of micronized caplets could possibly also be very helpful. Teflon at these high speeds may also need replaced. I know Teflon would work at the 100MPH range however we are talking close to the speed of sound for this Hyper Loop. Maybe an Aerogel or maybe slightly thicker with a hard surface liner? Within seconds of contact of the sponge gel touching the outer tube the gel would turn to liquid and reduce friction? Ok, so that idea may have other applications and may not be a good solution here. Next solution was to think of a friction less coupler working with magnets already so create a magnetic coupler and get rid of metal on metal friction and complexity. The complexity behind the magnetic will be very high however it will most likely be less routine maintenance, more computer systems. This would possibly be a much faster staging and decoupling in the station? Next is staging. This whole concept of super high speed is null if we are unable to have everyone staged up and ready to go? The time it takes to load rides at an amusement park vs the time standing in line vs the length of time the ride lasts? Ok, so this idea is to create a huge multi-platform staging station. How fast will each pod be able to move about on it's own? We could have slower speed local drops and higher speeds for merging into the main lines? This would require a lot of pressure doors while connecting to the main line however the local low speed runs would not need any. The overall design is so cramped and small that it is not like a subway where 100s may be boarding and departing at the same time. So each pod could be pre-boarded and those departing could be detaching from the main line prior to hitting the main terminal? I would love to set up an animation since a picture is worth this much and a video really brings the message home. My words are just not bringing my ideas to life here.

title: SlinkyBOT_Lunar mini rover
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Slinky has been conceived as an individual in a swarm of robots dedicated to exploring rough terrain (like the Lunar surface).The four legs of the Slinky-bot robot have independent movements. They are connected to the body by means of four continuous rotation drives with a feedback of the position. This configuration is very versatile and allows, at least, implement five different locomotion modes: â€˜slinky, â€˜rollingâ€™, â€˜caterpillarâ€™, â€˜quadrupedâ€™ and â€˜whegsâ€™. The two firsts modes have been selected as principal means of locomotion: â€˜slinkyâ€™ and â€˜rollingâ€™. The rest of the modes can be used punctually to overcome obstacles for a better adaptation. These modes base the movement in carrying out back flips or cartwheels. While the robot surface in relation to its mass, is wide, the pressure against the ground is low, which guarantees movement on any kind of surface; even though is sand or dust, avoiding in this way the wheels to be buried.
  • A complete description of the project can be found here: http://wp.me/p22sj0-b2
  • Video_Prototype Test: http://youtu.be/x9KxcwdDV3k

• 3D parts printed.
  • 4 mini servos.
  • 1 small microcontroller (Arduino mini)
  • 1 power supply
  • 1 Modem Bluetooth or Xbee
  • Glue, screws, screwdriver...

title: "400 mm  3d printed tricopter " made on replicator 2X

description.text:
OLD school 3d printed tricopter.

It was my first 3d printing project back in 2013. (on my replicator 2x)

Some of the STL were generated on a 1/10 scale. you will need to scale them ten time bigger.

Sometimes you gotta run before you can walk

It's design to work with an APM 2.5 (tight in space but it fit in)

I Have fly and crash this frame so many time without any major damage.
I plan to add upgrade if you people ask them.

You can leave your question in the comment section .

Have a nice day.

you only need 6-32 threaded screw and nut.

100 - 80 % infill recommended

layer between .15 mm and .3 mm.

All support structure are in the STL file.

You should be able to remove it only by hand.

It was design to be made with ABS plastic.

General advice from my little experience with abs plastic.

Test all part by prying them a little bit. If you hear a little brittle sound dip the part 1 sec in an acetone bowl and let it dry 24 hour. you can also use a brush to gently cover the part with acetone ( be quick or your brush will stick.)

author: raynor1212

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4n4VH3fXph2

I present the Pi-Cade: a completely 3D printed arcade cabinet built for the Raspberry Pi 2.

Inspired by the people over at adafruit and their cupcade project (http://www.adafruit.com/product/1783), and the folks over at retrobuiltgames.com (http://www.retrobuiltgames.com/the-build-page/porta-pi-arcade-kit/. I thought the cupcade concept was great, but with a tiny 2 inch screen the playability may be limited. Similarly, retrobuilt is a nice cabinet, but I thought the foot print could be much smaller and still remain very comfortable to use / play. And of course, I wanted a 3D printed version.

With a 7 inch screen, real arcade controls, an amplifier and 3 inch stereo speakers, this cabinet is the perfect size for a desk-top arcade! The system runs retropie, which uses emulationstation to manage various emulators. See their wiki for all the types of emulators that are supported: http://blog.petrockblock.com/retropie/

A quick video here:

https://youtu.be/lUAQfXKvS6g

This print is made up of fairly large parts, the largest of which is 240mm by 180mm, so at this time you will need a large print bed. The panels also require you to have your printer dialed in and leveled well for good results. If I get time, I may break up some of the larger panels to make this printable on smaller printers.

You can find everything you need to order on the instructions page, and almost everything is available at adafruit.com. I am going to continue to make design enhancements -- perhaps a 6 button panel, a two player version, and options for different controls.

The sketchup file is included for you to edit. The sketchup file does not have rounded edges on the front panels as the printable stl files do. I suggest round corner, with a 3mm setting to round over the sides of the front facing panels (see examples in the STLs).

Happy gaming!

Print all the parts. Choose your marquee panel from the 3 options provided, or use the blank one to make your own logo.

The panels go together using m4 machine screws, like these:
http://amzn.com/B000NHYR4K. You will need 4 longer m4 screws with nuts to attach the joystick. For some of the smaller holes (like the raspberry pie and the video boards, I use m3 versions of the same:
http://amzn.com/B000NHTPPQ. When connecting the pi, these cables always come in handy: http://amzn.com/B00D7SCMZ8.

The HDMI cable is a very tight fit, and you will need a flat style cable with short ends. I suggest something like this: http://amzn.com/B00APYQU4Q.

Here is the list of components from Adafruit:

2 Arcade Button - 30mm Translucent Red
http://www.adafruit.com/products/473#tutorials
2 Arcade Button - 30mm Translucent Blue
http://www.adafruit.com/products/476#tutorials
2 Arcade Button - 30mm Translucent Clear
http://www.adafruit.com/products/471#tutorials

Or obviously whatever colors you would like!

Stereo 2.8W Class D Audio Amplifier - I2C Control AGC - TPA2016
http://www.adafruit.com/products/1712#tutorials
Speaker - 3" Diameter - 4 Ohm 3 Watt
http://www.adafruit.com/products/1314#tutorials

The monitor:
http://www.adafruit.com/products/1933

You will need a Raspberry Pi model 2, and a wifi dongle, SD card, and plug, and a wireless mini keyboard. There are many "kits" available on adafruit, I will leave that to you.

I happen to like the american style joystick, as opposed to the japan style that adafruit sells. I will add an additional control panel for the adafruit option, but in the meantime the control panel is made for this joystick from amazon: http://amzn.com/B00EM34ZN4

This project will require some light soldering of the amp unit and speakers. For the buttons, I suggest these from adafruit, although soldering will obviously work: http://www.adafruit.com/products/1152

For this project, you do not need more than the pi 2 for connections to the GPIO. I splice all the grounds together, and use the Adafruit retro game utility to emulate keyboard commands from the joystick and the buttons. There is an excellent tutorial here, although the GPIO diagrams are a bit dated:

https://learn.adafruit.com/retro-gaming-with-raspberry-pi/buttons

Enjoy! Feel free to ask questions!

title: M5 nut holder for 10 series t-slot aluminum extrusion

description.text:
I designed these for 10 series aluminum extrusions that are 1" x 1" square.

key differences over others of the same, the nut is twisted to grab mor metal when tightened, and the corners are rounded for easier printing.

Long version:
As most know t-nuts are expensive $9 US for 25 and then $15 shipping which is outrageous so I used M5 nuts and bolts, I probably should have tried M6 but I couldn't find any at the hardware store and didn't want to buy 200 of something that I had to grind the edges off, all I could get at the hardware stores was 1/4" (grind it), M8 (way to big) and #8 screws (too small) so I went with something that I knew would grab but didn't need to be ground but they are too small to touch the sides and so would spin and would flop around in the channel so I printed some holders for the nuts, there were quite a few out there already but they all have the flats of the nuts parallel to the flats of the channel and they don't overlap that much so I could see over tightening the screws and it pulling out of the channel so I made some that the nut is turned so that it grabs as much of the channel as possible, I also rounded the edges for several reasons:

  1. Printers move faster along curves than they do corners.
  2. When printers do corners they can leave extra plastic as it pauses at the corners (on mine anyways)
  3. When printing without fans (I was using ABS as I have lots of it) the corners of things angled up REALLY start to angle up and if it comes to a point it will cause a bulge up at every corner that needs to be cut off.
  4. Less plastic made them print faster.

Update 8/27/2015:
I needed some holders with the nut closer to the edge to get in close to the corner of a printer I am making, I shortened just one side of the holder and included it as well and it is also in the sketchup file.

I printed them with ABS, not for any real reason other than I had a lot of out of spec ABS that I had unwittingly bought until I found a good brand.
0.4mm nozzle
0.2mm layer height
15% infill
240c hotend
110c bed
ABS juice to hold it down. ;-)

This is a mini version of a real sheet metal brake. They are usually used for bending sheet metal to form air ducts. The mini sheet metal I used is 36 gauge aluminum. You will need two 3/8" X 3/4" springs. It can cut up to 100mm wide.

Buy 36 gauge aluminum here http://tinyurl.com/olcvgct
Buy springs here http://tinyurl.com/naa4f6d
Watch video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fiXDhEaiYg0

A remix of Beer Bottle Lock( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:628847 ) which is a bottle top lock for craft beers. I customized it so different label files can be used and printed/reprinted easily. The text depth was increased slightly too. As Benjamin noted, many small luggage type locks will work( maybe these http://amzn.com/B00TEERR7W ). What I like about Benjamin's design was not only the OpenSCAD design file but the hinge requires no added hardware and is printed in place.

I printed this using Slic3r on my MIni Kossel printer in PLA using .2mm layers, 20% infill and no brim.

edit the bottle_lock.scad file looking for the "include" lines. There you'll see a number of lines with "//" in front of them and those lines are commented out. If you want to change a label file used comment out the current one in use and uncomment the one you want to use. Or create your own by copying one of the label-xxxx.scad files to your own name and add that as an include file. Export the STL file, slice, print and repeat.

This device is designed to take anything you draw on the smaller pad and reproduce it at 4X it's original size by doubling it in both x and y orientations. Similarly it can be used in reverse to shrink an image. Know now that I have not tested or printed this piece so I cannot confirm whether it is truly functional or if there are unforeseen design flaws. As well, these pieces are not designed to be printed as is and thus will likely need support material added before attempting a print.

title: Printrbot Metal Plus Dropcam Mount V2

description.text:
This is my heavy duty Dropcam mount. I liked the first one I made (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:881044) and I wanted a little more flexibility in view angles, so I made this one.

Link to Dropcam: http://goo.gl/wkz429

Warning this will not fit the Nest cam. The diameter of the nest cam is different then the Dropcam.

My Dropcam is live and can be viewed here: http://printrbot.rocks/

To adhere the mount to the print bed I use 3M VHB tape.

LINK to tape used: http://amzn.to/1V30GQT

I used 2 1/4"-20 3/4" stainless steel bolts and 2 1/4"-20 stainless steel nuts to assemble this. Also be sure to print 2 of the nut knobs.

Optional: I mounted the camera upside down and then zip tied the cable to itself (see pictures) to release the cable of strain. I had one cable die due to the motion of the print bed.

title: Lasercut leather mobile sleeve (changeable parameters for different phones)

description.text:
This is my first to laser cut leather. I made a protective mobile case made out of a thin, soft leather in petrol blue.

I designed the pattern in OpenSCAD and made it able to adapt to different phone sizes. A dxf for my phone (Sony Xperia Z3) is available as well.

Detailed instructions:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Laser-cut-mobile-sleeve/

Short:
Get some material that fits your style. I used a soft 1.2mm thick leather.

If you don't have a Xperia Z3 you need to load the scad file in OpenScad and change the parameters 'mobile_thickness', 'mobile_height' and
'mobile_width' to you phone size.
You need to modify the 'added_height_margin' and 'added_width_margin' as well to fit you type of corners. The parameters in the file are for very round corners (Xperia Z3). Add a bit more for sharp corners like iPhone 5.

After cutting you need to sew the parts together. Start at the bottom and go in a simple wave pattern though the holes up and down again. Don't pull to hard or you will get bumps.

title: Modified corner side gussets for 10 series aluminum extrusions 1" square

description.text:
I found Bill84s corner bracket and printed out a pair for my new printer but I was going to be using bolts instead of screws so where his support bracket in the back was wouldn't work for me as I couldn't get a socket in there (the irony is after all the modifications I ended up using screws) so I started modifying it, I cut the back support away but needed some sort of extra support in the corners of the brackets so I connected the tops then thought they would look better curved, then I was looking at it thinking "what a waste of plastic" and thought about cutting a triangle out but it wouldn't look very good and would give three sharp edges to crack at so I decided to cut circles out, it lessens the plastic used to save on plastic which causes it to print faster also, is extremely strong, and looks pretty cool.
I included the inside corner gusset that I created but did not end up printing it or using it but included it if someone wants it and the sketchup file.

Update 8/29/2015:
I made the bottom corners for a 0.5" gap but when putting my printer together I decided I wanted to use a power socket out of an old PC power supply but it was 0.75" tall so I made two new bottom corners with a 0.75" gap, I found a minor issue with the 0.5" ones so I fixed those as well, enjoy.

I printed them in ABS and PLA, PLA worked really well and was hard but I don't have air conditioning and a marble maze got hot enough for it to soften so decided ABS was a better choice.
if laid flat the piece that will print up will split easily, fuming the ABS helped but I am going to print them at an angle next time, if angled at a 45 degree angle on the top cura only shows support at the bottom and no where else but I have not tried printing it but I have not tried it yet, that would fix the easy to split part, lol or use a washer. ;-)

ABS
0.4mm nozzle
0.2mm layer height
40% infill (probably should have went solid)

description.text: (This is all new code, but it was inspired by whosawhatsis'. And I have designed it so that you should be able to use this code in place of whosawhatsis' with no issues). Basically this is a better parametric teardrop. I wanted to be able to create teardrop hex nut holes, so I added a parameter for number of sides - which then means that you naturally want a few more parameters as well. File has been updated to version 2, original version can still be downloaded if you wish.

The parameters are... teardrop make sure to only specify one radius or diameter parameter - there are several to choose from "r" or "or" specify the maximum or outer radius of the object, "ir" specifies the minimum or inner radius "d", "od" and "id" are the same for specifying in terms of diameter - "id" is useful for specifying the across flats distance for nuts "length" is the length of the teardrop "angle" is the angle from vertical of the teardrop - 0 degrees is a vertical hole, 90 degrees is horizontal "fn" is the number of sides of the 'cylinder' - set to 6 for a teardrop hex nut "angle2" is the rotation of the 'cylinder' around its axis

title: FrSky FLVSS LiPo voltage checker case

description.text:
FrSky FLVSS is a voltage sensor intended to relay battery information over a SmartPort connection. However the bright OLED display and small size makes it a perfect tool to carry and check you lipo voltage.

This case is designed to better protect the FLVSS when carried around the field, yet still be very minimal, not much larger than the PCB itself. In order to keep the size down I removed the original foil covering as well as the unused pins for the smart port and LED. The case should fit without these modifications, but the cover cannot be used.

[Update]
Added version of the case with a small notch to indicate which pin is ground. (FLVSS_case_ground_notch.stl) Shows up best when printed in light colored filaments, as the connector behind the notch is black.

title: QUBD OneUp/TwoUp Carriage and Bowden mount

description.text:
Just a remix of Rcaslis QUBD OneUp/TwoUp extruder bearing holder thing 408818. Mushed version of Tech2C's E3D v6 Bowden X-carriage mount Prusa i3, now for the QUBD OneUp. ;-)

The left gantry mod is a remix from Stefan Burger. Other than the obvious I made the screw holes for the heads just a bit larger as I screwed my first one up trying to drill them out and went too far. Stefan did all the work, I just tweaked it to fit my needs.

My X-Gantry replacement left and right sides didn't match up quite right with the replacement carriage, it was about 1mm too large putting too much pressure on my bearings making them glide horribly. This remix removed that 1mm so it should be smoother. You can edit it to match yours pretty easily, just grab it off my Tinkercad account, also express405. I then noticed that the left side of the X-Gantry takes up more space than the original setup so I sliced the carriage rather than the beefy left side, using the bouden extruder so I'm not too concerned with the narrower bearings. I've even placed the holes on the carriage to match up with the Bowden mount. The Bowden mount was too long so I shortened it a bit to fit the OneUp printing area. Now it is just too high, definitely a work in progress.

I really like elmuchacho's Mini Kossel frame brace (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:626279) and B0rax's glass holder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:538746). However, unfortunately, they dont quite work together. As a result, I've made this Thing.

It works seamlessly with the frame brace and looks friggin' badass. I've included cutouts for an FSR with a circle of cork on top of it as well as cutouts for two additionally cork circles to provide a cushion for the glass.

NOTE: This is intended for the standard Kossel Mini with 240mm cross members and 1515 extrusions. If there is enough interest (leave a comment) I will modify the model to support 2020 extrusions or whatever else.

UPDATE 9/20/2015: Added "pad.stl" and "pad_fsr.stl". These are to fill in the cutouts in the bracket. Initially I intended to use cork, but instead I decided to print these out of NinjaFlex. You can of course still just cut out circles from cork and use that instead.

comments.text: Yeah sorry I haven't updated this. I've been procrastinating on finishing it up. The bed I have is actually an aluminum plate that I cut custom. However before I did that, I had a glass one. I had intended to provide a cutting template for the bed and I still intend to do so. However since it sounds like you're on a tight schedule, I wanted to respond quickly with the broad strokes of how I did it so you didn't need to wait on me. Basically I just bought a glass sheet from Home Depot for like $4 and a glass cutter with it. Then I marked (I modeled the parts, so I already knew what the measurements needed to be, but you'll need to measure the distance across each plate to the other to determine what size your cuts should be. Once I had that, I used a ruler as a straight edge to guide the glass cutter. I tapped each edge off with slight pressure. The last bit is the trickiest. The sharp points at each vertex need to be "chamfered". Really they just need to be made not pointy or they wont fit in the mounts. I just marked them as best I could freehand with the glass cutter and then used some needle nose pliers to break the tips off. In reality, the cleanliness of that step isnt super important; it's just to make it fit properly.

description.text:
Free spinning spool holder that mounts magnetically.

I printed the 3" version. In retrospect, it could have been longer. If it gives me any trouble I will print out the 4" long version.

Designed for Ultimaker brand filament spools.

The cart we put our Ultimaker2 on has steel side panels.

1x 5/16"-18 x 3" Full Thread Hex Bolt
2x 5/16"-18 Nylock Nuts
1x 1/4 flat washer
4x 608 bearings (probably don't really need this many)

Disc Magnet Mount I found at Ace.

I had to open up the hole in the magnet from 1/4" to 5/16"

Also, the holes for the bearings are a bit tight. I had to squeeze them in using a bolt and nut (and a little hammer).

I put a very thin rubber band around the spool holder to grip the spool and make sure it doesn't walk off the holder.

Uses a 7/16" drill bit, small piece of aluminum bar stock (available at lowes), drill press, C Clamp and Chinese soup container to chop up filament. Also needs 4 M3 X 25 mm bolts with nuts/washers. Most of the pellets come out real small, some are longer, but still mostly broken so they break easy in your hand. If the piece of metal was brought closer to the drill bit the larger pieces would probably be eliminated, but at the risk of any drill bit wobble making metal bits (experiment and let me know what you find). A drop of mineral oil prevent heat build up from the shaft of the drill bit rubbing along the plastic. Move the devices all the way up on the drill bit so the cutting section stops below where the abs rubs the drill bit. If you don't, pellets will ride up into this cavity and generate heat and melt, causing issues.

One benefit of this design is that its very easy to remove the piece of metal and examine it to be sure there has been no metal shavings created.

Update #1: If you chamfer the hole in the aluminum bar with a larger drill bit, the filament will feed much easier. Without this, filament with bends/curves can catch on the edge.

Update #2: I drilled it out to 1/2" so there is less space between drill bit and the aluminum piece. If there is too much room, abs won't chip, it just chews at it and leaves it intact. I found it works much better if you actually use push to connect fittings. Tap the aluminum block and drill out the upper plastic piece so the fitting fits. I also finally got my setup motorized. See video: https://youtu.be/G9oXTAJCpPA

Print in ABS with 40% or more infill so you can clamp it to the drill press bed without damage.

Use a drop of mineral oil where the drill bit rubs the device.

title: Functional Rick and Morty Portal Gun Prop

description.text:
Checkout the Mk 2: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1071966

Portal gun from Rick and Morty. Made this for a birthday gift...I rushed a lot of it since I had a two week deadline. I used what I had lying around...hence the blue 7 segment display...it's from alternate Rick...my excuse...

I'd upload some pictures of the circuit board...but that would mean partial deconstruction of a gift that I've already given away...I'd feel really guilty...

Video - https://youtu.be/0jZOc7ff73s
Not the best quality...the long ending is to show the auto-off feature (30 long seconds).

Parts List:
1x 4 Digit 7 Segment - https://www.sparkfun.com/products/11405
1x Atmega328 - https://www.sparkfun.com/products/10524
1x 16 MHz Resonator - https://www.sparkfun.com/products/9420
1x 28 Pin Dip Socket - https://www.sparkfun.com/products/7942
4x 1K Ohm Resistor (For Pull-Ups and Current Limiting) - Where ever...
5x 330 Ohm Resistor (For 7 Segment Display and Speaker) - Where ever...
2x 1N4001 Diode (I used Schottkeys...my bag of 1000x 1N4001 is hiding from me...) - https://www.sparkfun.com/products/8589
1x 2n3904 NPN Transistor - https://www.sparkfun.com/products/521
1x Radioshack 275-0240 Relay (Only small relay I had...) - http://www.radioshack.com/5vdc-1a-spdt-micro-relay/2750240.html
1x 5V Boost Regulator - http://www.ebay.com/itm/5PCS-PFM-Control-DC-DC-USB-0-9V-5V-to-5V-dc-Boost-Step-up-Power-Supply-Module-/400520469462
1x 3 AAA Holder - http://www.ebay.com/itm/6-3-AAA-Size-Battery-Dry-Cell-Holder-Box-DC-Case-bc3aaa-/180382798706
1x 8 Ohm Speaker - https://www.sparkfun.com/products/10722
1x Rotary Encoder - http://www.ebay.com/itm/12mm-Rotary-Encoder-Push-Button-Switch-Keyswitch-Electronic-Components-Effective-/231410073065
1x Rotary Encoder Knob - Couldn't source, print one?
3x AAA - Where ever...
4x WS2812 LEDs (one for top and 3 for front) - http://www.ebay.com/itm/WS2811-WS2812-5050-RGB-LED-strip-Light-Waterproof-Individually-Addressable-DC5V-/111164910188
1x T10 Bulb - https://www.google.com/shopping/product/16565885857852949835

Note that all these components are really generic...feel free to swap parts in where you can (Sparkfun is more expensive than Mouser, Digikey, Ebay, or the dumpster). Most of my parts came from stuff I got out of the dumpster... One thing that came in handy where a bunch of 0.1 spaced JST connectors that I got out of an old CD player. I'd like to make a much smaller board. The resistor used for the speaker can be swapped out for a lower value to make it louder. Be careful not to draw more than 20mA (recommended continuous current draw) from a pin. I tested my speaker without a resistor...highest current pulled was ~18mA (guessing this is because the sound is not continuous).

I highly recommend using connectors between the 7 segment, rotary encoder, front panel lights, and the crystal light to the main board. I used some JST connectors I found in an old cd play (from the dump). I used an 8 pin (only using 7 of the pins for the 7 segment), two 5 pins (using 4 pins for the 7 segment from one and all pins for the rotary encoder), a 3 pin (LED), and two 2 pins (one for the battery and one for the speaker). I can't seem to source the ones I used, their wires are in a different order that standard JST connectors (not that this really matters).

WARNING!!! BE CAREFUL WITH WIRE ORDER, I WAS GOING FOR A SINGLE SIDED BOARD, SO THERE ARE MANY NON-SYMMETRIC PINOUTS!!!

Instructions:

  1. Print out stls.
  2. Mill or order PCBs files.
  3. Populate PCBs. I used JST connectors for everything. Using connectors makes life a ton easier when assembling this thing. I used schottky diodes in the "main.brd" file because that's all I had on hand.
  4. Upload firmware and test all the electronics together BEFORE assembly.
  5. Glue handle sides together (I used superglue).
  6. Insert the "knob" board into the handle slot.
  7. Glue handle to the body (I used superglue).
  8. Cover the rotary encoder with tape.
  9. Sand...fill in gaps with filler (I used Elmers Wood Filler)...sand...primer...repeat...
  10. Paint body.
  11. Put in "led" board.
  12. Find a cylinder like lightbulb.
  13. Cut it in half with a dremel.
  14. Tape the sharp edges.
  15. Create a "crystal" over one of the WS2812 leds with hot glue.
  16. Hot glue "crystal" inside the lightbulb.
  17. Fill lightbulb with a clear resin.
  18. Insert lightbulb to assembly.
  19. Cut and drill a front cover from plastic (I used a mill and the Eagle file named plate.brd).
  20. Paint front plate if necessary.
  21. Glue WS2812 LEDs to the front plate.
  22. Attach front plate to assembly (I ended up drilling the holes manually rather than using my mill since I had self tapping screws).
  23. Done.

comments.text: In my reply to gust242 I explained where the schematics and board layouts are (they are in the files). I did use an Arduino, the board I made has a minimal Arduino circuit on it (atmega328 and 16MHz resonator). The code is also included under portal_code.zip. title: ROB-O Junior FFF 3D Printer using 80/20s 10/10 (1"x1") extrusion

description.text:
I know, I know, we need another 3D printer design like we need a hole in our heads but.....

I love the Ultimaker with a passion, in my opinion it is THE printer to beat, it has the smallest layer height of a personal FFF printer I have found and in my drooling but lack of $2773 US dollars (at the moment) there was no way I could have one so at looking at it and dreaming of it I realized that I could do that and if I use a CoreXY mechanism I might even improve on it.

so I made a scratch built printer from wood, nylon sheets, L shaped angle aluminum, wire ties and hot glue and it works really well but it could be better, you can see those exploits here http://rob-o-printer.blogspot.com/
I bought new printer parts to rebuild it but didn't want to tear it down so decided to take all the parts and use it to make a smaller printer and then use that printer to rebuild the bigger one so here it goes.
I have everything designed, I have to print a couple more parts that I had to tweak but I will not add any parts to this that I have not printed and tested, so far the frame is done and I am working at printing some 12mm shaft clamps now to get the XY carriage installed into the frame so I can work out the motor mounts.

In learning from my mistakes with ROB-O I am working at correcting them with R.J. btw I suck at names and was thinking robo printer but it exists but since my name is Rob I am going with Rob - O Printer until I can think of something better.

So some differences between mine and Ultimaker besides the build volume is that I am using a CoreXY mechanism which Ultimaker has a unique way of getting some of the same properties in a smaller space.
The other thing that I have learned and am excited to try that is different is getting the Z shafts and the Z screw off of the same plane, with them all being in a row it seems to cause more tension on the three, you are suspending a bed and just holding it on the edge with 3 shafts, on this design I am staggering the shafts and the screw pulling the Z shafts back a bit, that gives it a three point stand and that hopefully get rid of all the flex at the far end of the bed. I will let you know if that idea pans out.

To get an idea of what it can do check this link out, it was done with the "Bubblegum" printer lol i.e. it is held together by bailing wire and bubblegum, if it can do this good of a job I can wait to see how well R.J. does as it has no slop in the heads at all.
http://rob-o-printer.blogspot.com/2015/04/height-test.html

My next update will be the CoreXY mechanism build.

List of printed parts I have used so far.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:980961
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:980981
Dual CoreXY setup
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:990244

Update 8/25/2015:
I added a couple pics of the corexy mechanism in place, it is not the final parts or final shafts but I wanted to get a better idea of where everything was going so used some test prints I had kicking around.
The X carriage is printing now and it should be the final working version, if so I will post it as a separate thing, I left room for z probes etc.
In the STL model is a version of the X and Y parts if you want a closer look for now.

Update 8/29/2015:
I finished my version of the CoreXY mechanism everything lines up and works now, I just need to make the corner bearing mounts and the motor mounts and it will be fully functional.

Update 9/11/2015:
I will be posting new pictures etc this weekend, I had to do a lot of rework on the coreXY mechanism, keeping the belt inside the frame hanging down was just not going to work with the corner pieces and were too big of a pain so I went with just the motors outside on the sides with the filament extruders and bearings in the corner, I reprinted the parts and everything is lining up, I just need to print some more bearing flanges and should have it all hooked up and hopefully wired together and printing this weekend.
I will update the corexy with the new parts and the motor mounts probably tomorrow.

Update 9/25/2015:
I have everything hooked up but the hotends and the extruders and told it to print, told it to do a print speed of 150mm/s and a move speed of 300mm/s and it didn't blink an eye, I cranked it to 999% and it flew, I doubt it could push the plastic out that fast especially as I normally use a 0.3mm nozzle but the mechanism handled it just fine and flew, it was a glorious sight.

Update 9/26/2015:
I have it completely assembled and printing.
It is printing beautifully, I am going to use it to reprint all the parts in the final colors then I will document the assembly, etc. when I put the new parts in, I may even do a build video or two.
I ended up going with a silicone heat mat for the heat source it is the same price as the circuit board but much more efficient.

Update 10/12/2015:
Everything is up and printing and working nicely but I have encountered two issues.

  1. Hotends get jammed.
  2. Bed bounces.
    for #1
    I had designed the fan to blow across and then the exit path for the air was up so it couldn't blow the hot air towards the plastic and I figured that was the cause of the jams so I opened it up to blow straight accross.... nope.
    I realized cura was retracting 16mm on hotend change, set it to 5 thinking it was pulling the molten plastic up too far... nope.
    I only printed with one hotend and everything worked flawlessly so I am thinking the fan is not blowing hard enough to cool both hotends so I ordered a 40mm x 40mm x 20mm fan that blows roughly 3 times more than the one I have, hopefully it will be here by the weekend, will update if that cures it.

for #2 the shape of the bed is rectangular, the Z axis is on one of the short ends, if I was to put the Z axis on the side of the printer I would have to extend that side of the bed for it to reach and again would be causing it to be a rectangle held on the short end so there is a lot of bounce on the far end and I mean A LOT, every time the head moves the bed shakes.
I ordered two 8mm shafts and bearings for the front corners of the bed, that SHOULD keep it from bouncing around and still allow it to move up and down, may have to have it home slower but printing at 0.2 - 0.02 layers like I normally do is slow enough for it not to bind during a normal print.
I have the parts but have not had time to make it yet.
I have had lots of ideas but this was the easiest, a great idea was to have a high 2" plate in the back top and bottom that then goes from their down each side tapering to the end of the bed but it would almost need to be one solid peice and it would add a lot of weight and the bed and build plate is heavy enough as it is.
The Ultimaker has the same issue and the result is ghosting, on the ultimaker a lot of people slow down and print towards the Z mount, I want to find a way to let me print normally and get better results.

All of that said I will probably make another corexy setup that is for 8mm shafts, I went 12mm because that is what I had on hand for my 20" print bed printer but for a smaller printer 12mm is mega overkill and add so much more weight, almost double the weight.

Update 10/17/2015
I managed to get rid of a good 80% of the bed bounce by just changing the Z motor coupler.
I was using a flex coupler that I bought and it is cut like a spring so it could flex, problem is supporting the weight of the bed it also bounces up and down like a spring.
I swapped it out for a solid coupler that I printed and most of the bed bounce is gone.
I had left the top of the threaded rod open like Ultimaker but it wobbles a bit so I ordered a radial bearing today and will design a holder for it that will hold the other end solid but able to spin and I think the bed issues will be a thing of the past.
The main issue is that the aluminum is so heavy I think I went too thick on the actual build plate so I think I am going to pick up a 3mm plate which will cut the weight by almost half which between that and the coupler/bearing should eliminate all of the bed bounce/z wobble.

Update 10/24/2015:
Added STL and SKP files for:
Z-Motor mount
Z-Motor coupler
12mm shaft mount
12mm cut down shaft mount for mounting the Y-axis shafts as close to the sides as I could.
Z-axis bearing/bed holder designed for a 1/8" thick aluminum plate.
Plate mounts to mount the lower and upper bottom plates to the extruded aluminum to cover the electronics.

Sorry I forgot those, between here and my linked items should be everything required to make the printer.

For the Z wobble I made a new Z motor coupler that is taller on the ball screw side, the other one I had only caught about 1/2" of the shaft, I made one that was taller and thicker, what a difference it made, you can hardly see the shaft move at the top of the printer as the bed lifts.
I am still going to add a 12mm bearing at the top to hold the ball screw solid since it also supports the bed.

Update 11/17/2015
I have uploaded the new z-axis, new z-coupler, 12mm clamps, PSU mounts, and LME12UU to LMK12UU Adapter.
I am not using the z-axis as my bed is too big and is putting too much pressure by being supported by just one set of smooth shafts and ball screw.
I am now using four shafts and two ball screws and used the LME12UU to LMK12UU adapter that I made and between that and the other enancements that I have made I have nice beautifully straight no z-wobble prints.
After 8 months this project is finally coming to an end.
I redesigned the XY motor mounts and will be installing them as soon as they are done printing, all I have left to do after that is to reprint some corner pieces and the bowden feeders, but only to match my color scheme that I chose.
I will be uploading the dial color corner brackets soon.

Update 11/23/2015
I rigged up an external driver board and am using some DRV8825 drivers that I had on hand, everything is so much quieter now, most moves are quieter than the fans.
I am still thinking about getting some stepsticks to see if it is even quieter.
I mounted the pi in the bottom of the printer, one more board mount and I can put the top plate on (top of the bottom section)
Left to do is to:
1 make a cable chain for the heated bed power cable and thermistor cable to keep them out of the way.
2 mount the display back board (I split the display into it's 2 boards, mounted the smaller display board up front, and the control board in the printer connected via a ribbon cable.)

  1. mount the top plate of the bottom section.
  2. modify the active cooling fan ducts for PLA printing to make them better.
  3. print the new corners so that they all match, can't decide between black & red, black & green or black & light blue trim.
    I have uploaded some new pictures and here are some sample videos, the first two videos tests are 30mm tall, the second two is the top and bottom of a raspberry pi mount that I modified just a touch to make the mount holes take a m5 nut.
    https://youtu.be/yZ2oPVkd5Q0
    https://youtu.be/gW-vZQhFuCA
    https://youtu.be/Yig9ltrEHdI
    https://youtu.be/Ke1T3y6frk4

Update 11/25/2015
I cut the notches in the cover plate for the electronics plate today but it is in the middle of a long print making a cable chain to keep the bed heater/thermistors out of the way so I just set it there for now.
I have updated the parts list for the printer and I updated the parts list for the CoreXY mechanism I made.
I forgot to list in my last update that I modified the bearing bushings and the motor mounts on the 23rd so the parts are ready to go.
The last part I need to design is the active cooling fan ducts which go on last anyways so get to printing and building already will ya.... :-)

If anyone runs into any snags message me, I have learned a lot designing my printer, even the parts I used to start it that I remixed are not used in it anymore I went other directions, the main one I kept and kept intact was the extruder, IMHO it is the best extruder design that I have used.

Update 12/15/2015
I added a better Z endstop, before I just had a hall effect sensor next to the threaded shaft and a magnet mounted at the end of a screw mounted on the bed so it came dead on to the hall effect sensor, that is not very reliable.
I have made a hall effect sensor mount that mounts to the side of the frame so it can be raised and lowered, and a magnet holder that mounts to the edge of the bed, instead of approaching head on the to the sensor it now passes past the front of the sensor increasing the reliability of the Z position.
it wasn't hugely off the other way just enough to be annoying being either too close or too far away.

Update 3/16/2017
I have made some subtle changes to make the printer even better, I will be adding those parts soon, sorry for not updating more often.

Update 3/18/2017
Added v3 of the Z coupler, the 12mm ball screw has such a big space between the threads that when you tighten a set screw it throws the ball screw off of true so I threaded the coupler so you screw the coupler onto the shaft and then tighten it down, it gives it less room to move out of true.
I will be changing it once more eventually with a 3 set screw situation to even make it easier to be true.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:990244
Added a new XY Motor mount to my coreXY setup linked above that includes a bearing holder to hold a 12mm ID bearing to hold the top of the ball screw.
The ball screw is just a little loose so a perfect fix is a piece of heat shrink tubing on the top of the ball screw, when the bearing is slid down it fits nice and snug and centered.
I updated the parts list to what I am currently using, I need to update the extruders to the new gear as it is larger in diameter, I am currently working on that now.
I switched to a 110v heated bed that just runs off of the mains, and uses a solid state relay to activate, it is easier on the board as I have burned up connectors and a board itself running 12v heaters, added benefit is that it gets hotter much faster.

Stay tuned for more.

I am blogging the build of this at my rob-o printer blog.
http://rob-o-printer.blogspot.com/2015/08/rob-o-junior-frame-build.html

Cut the aluminum extrusions into 4 21" pieces, and 12 15" pieces.
To get everything you need cut 2 - 21" pieces from one then the rest of that piece cut into 15" pieces, do the same for the second piece and then cut the third piece into 15" pieces and you will have hardly any waste left over.

Print 8 of the side corner gussets from the description, and 4 of the bottom left and 4 of the bottom right side corner gussets.
I ended up printing 3 plates of the nut holders.

Bowden:
I am not using quick release compression fittings, I hate them, they are not quick or are too quick i.e. you can't get the bowden out or it pops out on it's own so I am using perm compression fittings, so you slide the nut on then the compression ring, tighten it down real well with a wrench (I don't do that part with the coupler mounted, I compress it outside of the printer with two wrenches so no plastic is stripped) then you just screw the nut down finger tight, easy peasy no fuss. After compressing the first time gently twist a 4mm drill bit in the tube to make sure it clears the path a little in case you got a little tightness happy.

Belts:
For belt tension, I learned a lesson, you can pull the head out of square by pulling one belt tighter than the other, here is my trick for overcoming this the simplest way.
Measure how long the belt should be by feeding it through, cut that belt leaving just a bit extra to grab onto, then cut another belt to the same length, line them up on the teeth cutting at the teeth so each belt has the same amount of teeth.
Put one belt in tightening it up nicely then after it is in place count the number of teeth extra that are hanging off and then put the other belt in place and make sure you have it tight enough so that it has the same amount of extra teeth hanging out and since the frame is square and the distances are all the same it all should be at the same tension and nice and square.

Linear Bearings:
when you look at a bearing down through the hole you can turn it until the bearings look like an X or a + if you have them all in the same orientation then the spot with the spaces will eventually get some slop in that direction, you can feel it when you put the bearings in a part and on the shaft, but if you stagger them then everything tightens up rock solid.
So for the head you would want :
----X----+-----
----+----X-----
if the ------ was the shaft going through the bearing, there is absolutely no slop that way then you want to do the same on the Y axis

X +
  • X
    | |

so the completed setup would be:

X----+----X-----+

+----X----+-----X
| |

Doing that makes for a rock solid setup, I didn't do that on my original printer and it has a lot of slop, the new one I cannot feel it move at all when I try twisting it and moving it around by hand.
That little thing makes a huge difference.

Heated bed:
Go with a silicone mat heater, same price, less current and no concern of it shorting out against the aluminum.

I am not saying "Buy these at amazon" but that is where I got them so I am including the name and the link, there are probably far cheaper places to get them.

comments.text:
Thank you for your opinion, I appreciate your viewpoint, my opinion is that corexy is better and so I used it.
The way the fan ducts are it blows on the plastic and barely hits the nozzle and misses the hot zone.
If you are concerned you can insulate the hotend like most do with glass tape and then use a different cooling design.
No one says that this is the perfect and right method, this is just my method and my opinion on setting things up, my design does not have any ghosting and I have printed down to 0.01mm with no issues other than that many layers took forever.
I love the ultimaker and from what I have seen of other cartesian printers I will say that if anything can beat mine in quality of prints it will be the ultimaker.

Correction it is running the a4982 which to me is worse than the 4988. the 4988 can do 1,2,4,8,16 microsteps, the a4982 can do 1,2,4,16 so even if I cut a trace and went that route it would not go to 8 steps.
After my rant last night I had one of the built in drivers blow for no reason, motor is good, no loose connections, was actively cooled, and was set to only 1.2 amps and it blew in the the middle of a print, the motor locks on solid and cannot be moved.
So yeah... don't get a smoothieboard.
I am rigging up external drivers for it now.

comments.text:
I put all the newly designed parts in today.
I need to tweak the 12mm clamp so that the magnet holder for the hal effect clears a bit better, and I am going to raise xy motor mount top about 1 mm to clear the extruded aluminum edge a little better but a washer could do the same as a stop gap but I will have those changes made tomorrow.
I have been printing with it for a few months now, I just keep improving it instead of reprinting the corners in black and letting it go.
In putting in the parts tonight I found my last alignment issue, using a plastic encases bearing, apparently the plastic distorted and was out of round.
I will have all the new parts list and everything I can think of updated this weekend.
as far as the smoothie board goes I actually regret buying it, yes I can move the carriage around a lot faster as it handles the coreXY better than the ramps style board but you can still only push plastic out so fast.
What I hate about it is the standard 4988 drivers are noisy as hell, the 12amp rated connectors burned out with only 10 amps.
The rest is either smoothieware or hardware unsure, but I have it setup to turn on the extruder fan when it gets to a certain temp, well sometimes that doesn't happen and so since I didn't notice causes a jam eventually and I have to power it off and back on again to get it to work.
same can happen with the cooling fans, if you go to cooldown in the menu it only cools one head.
I am going to make a second printer but with a 8mm shaft corexy using my old ultimaker 1 clone board and I am sure it will work just fine with less headache, with the ramps style you can't do over like 120mm moves without the then sounding like it is going to rip itself apart which from my research is a lack of processing power issue one motor stops before the other causing it to slam hard, but if you keep everything under 100 which for the 0.3mm nozzle I use normally it has to be way lower than that to get the infill to fill in enough, larger nozzles you can crank higher.
I have pictures of the parts and will take some of the printer tomorrow and post them.

title: Samsung Galaxy Note-3 Gear Neo 2 Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a stand / charger stand for the Note3 and a Galaxy Gear Neo2 ( Any version Note or Galaxy series (S5/S6 Etc.) will likely fit ).

It holds the base charger for the Gear Neo and has button that allows you to release your watch from the cradle.

The stand will fit bare phones, all the way up to Otter-box's.

(In the pictures the button is broken off, I have changed to a 2 piece design that solves this problem and speeds up print time)

Revision:
8/24/15 Updated Neo_Charger_Holder_RC1.stl with better button structure. Bigger USB Port. Charger cable wire holder channel

Print the watch cradle with high infill for strength.

The cradle has small screw holes and you can glue the two pieces together.

The phone stand can be printed without supports.

The watch cradle should be printed on its back with supports.

title: Body post stiffener for Tamiya MF-01X and M05 chassis

description.text:
Tall body shells, like the Suzuki Jimny, wobble horribly with the supplied body mounts in the Tamiya MF-01X or M05 kit.

These stiffening items improve the situation drastically. They attach to the existing body posts with snap pins.

Made in OpenSCAD, source included, so you can easily change it to suit other cars.

We had great results printing in ABS with 100% in-fill.
Clean up the holes for the body posts by running a 5.5 mm drill through them if necessary.

author: LANEBoysRC

description.text:
The fake knife switch actually mounts OVER THE EXISTING PLATE, which makes this design safer than the previous one, because we all know that PLA does not meet the eletrical code safety standards.

IGOR! Raise the switch! Muhahahahaaa It's aliiiiiiiiiiiiiive!!!!!!!!!!

Thanks goes to Jeff (aka LoboCNC), for it's original design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:649284.

Either print the plate or the plain plate, if you don't want the wood lines. This will need extreme bridging, give it a try, it's a nice challenge. After printing just cut out the switch rectangular hole and punch both screw holes with a drill bit.

The plate actually mounts OVER THE EXISTING PLATE, which makes this design safer than the previous one, because we all know that PLA does not meet the eletrical code safety standards.

Gently squeeze the handle into the plate.

The rocker will snug fit the actual switch, it may require a little dab of glue just to make sure it stays there.

The knob can be printed with Flexible plastic, for extra coolness, but if you print it with hard plastic, scale it up a bit.

Also, don't forget to yell "IGOR, RRRAISE THA SWITCH!!" every time you turn the light on.... :)

Just added the files for double, triple and even quadruple gang switches. Use the narrow handle for these. And also be prepared for insane bridging on the quad...

comments.text:
I love this idea of leaving the original plate in place. Beyond safety, I'm likely to lose the original plate when it's time to go back to it.
Currently printing this one in process. Hope to be able to extend it for multiple switch assemblies in the near future
comments.author: entropygun

comments.text: Lucky you, I was thinking about it, and you sparked me into drawing them. Good luck on printing the quad, most printers are too small for it...

title: Replacement diffuser for japanese ODELIC wall light

description.text:
I knocked mine off the wall. It broke. This is a direct replacement for the ODELIC light. There is a SCAD file and an STL file. Print using 0.3 layer height using white filament. Afterwards, I would use only LED bulbs in the fixture - I am sure the PLA would melt under a 60 watt.

Model number is either:
KR60W
0B080488
or
ML1036
I used the makerbot 5th gen. 0.3mm layer height, on blue tape. Print the part, and use superglue to re-attach it to the curved lamp part.
